t: Proverbs 27
Boast*p not thyself of to morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.
Let*p another man praise thee, and not thine own mouth; a stranger, and not thine own lips.
A*p stone is heavy, and the sand weighty; but a fool's wrath is heavier than them both.
Wrath*p is cruel, and anger is outrageous; but who is able to stand before envy?
Open*p rebuke is better than secret love.
Faithful*p are the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.
The*p full soul loatheth an honeycomb; but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.
As*p a bird that wandereth from her nest, so is a man that wandereth from his place.
Ointment*p and perfume rejoice the heart: so doth the sweetness of a man's friend by hearty counsel.
Thine*p own friend, and thy father's friend, forsake not; neither go into thy brother's house in the day of thy calamity: for better is a neighbour that is near than a brother far off.
My*p son, be wise, and make my heart glad, that I may answer him that reproacheth me.
A*p prudent man foreseeth the evil, and hideth himself; but the simple pass on, and are punished.
Take*p his garment that is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.
He*p that blesseth his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.
A*p continual dropping in a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.
Whosoever*p hideth her hideth the wind, and the ointment of his right hand, which bewrayeth itself.
Iron*p sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.
Whoso*p keepeth the fig tree shall eat the fruit thereof: so he that waiteth on his master shall be honoured.
As*p in water face answereth to face, so the heart of man to man.
Hell*p and destruction are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.
As*p the fining pot for silver, and the furnace for gold; so is a man to his praise.
Though*p thou shouldest bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, yet will not his foolishness depart from him.
Be*p thou diligent to know the state of thy flocks, and look well to thy herds.
For*p riches are not for ever: and doth the crown endure to every generation?
The*p hay appeareth, and the tender grass sheweth itself, and herbs of the mountains are gathered.
The*p lambs are for thy clothing, and the goats are the price of the field.
And*p thou shalt have goats' milk enough for thy food, for the food of thy household, and for the maintenance for thy maidens.
